awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Models, Algorithms, Simulations, and Applications for Three-Phase Systems with Solidification and Moving Contact Lines
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop mathematical models and numerical algorithms to address challenges in modeling fluids with multiple phases such as liquid, solid and ice. Phenomena with multiple fluid phases play an important role in many natural phenomena and industrial applications, such as atmospheric icing, additive manufacturing, and thermal spraying.  For example, when a rain drop impacts onto a cold solid surface, it spreads on the solid and at the same time freezes due to the low temperature. The physical problem involves three phases (liquid, solid of the same material, and air) and the interfaces are governed by different physics. The numerical models to be developed will advance the understanding of the underlying physics and provide guidance to the design of icephobic surfaces for aircrafts, 3D printers, and thermal spraying devices. Students will be involved and trained in the computational mathematics and interdisciplinary aspects of this project.

This project has the following goals: (i) to derive a variational phase-field model to describe the evolution of the solidification front as well as the liquid-air interface, with the consideration of contact line dynamics, non-equilibrium solidification, and variable density/viscosity; (ii) to develop efficient, easy-to-implement, and energy-stable numerical schemes with discrete energy laws for the proposed models; and (iii) to perform numerical simulations to validate the models and numerical schemes, and further study physically motivated problems. The model satisfies a physically consistent energy law, which is a necessary condition for a faithful description of real physics. The developed numerical schemes are energy-stable with the advantage of allowing large time steps, which is particularly important to this multi-physics problem with disparate time scales. The developed codes will allow us to simulate the solidification of flowing drops made of different materials in a wide variety of applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The solidification dynamics of a liquid drop impacting onto a cold surface are governed by the intricate nonlinear coupling of several key factors: (i) interfacial morphology; (ii) macroscopic hydrodynamics; (iii) contact line dynamics; (iv) liquid-solid anisotropic solidification during cooling; and (v) heat transfer. These systems are not only fundamental to understanding natural processes but also find practical relevance in advanced manufacturing technologies, such as 3D printing, thermal spraying for smart coatings, and the fabrication of functional surfaces. This dynamic system is highly interactive: the anisotropic solidification process deforms the interface and modifies the flow field near the contact line, while the altered flow, in turn, impacts heat transfer, thereby influencing the phase transition dynamics. The feedback loop between these processes introduces significant complexity, with the mechanisms driving interfacial singularities and deformation dynamics being heavily dependent on the interplay among all these factors.

There are few, if any, guiding principles for such experimental studies, with very limited predictive capability. Modeling and simulations of these phenomena can, therefore, play an important role in interpreting experiments and ultimately identifying accurate theories and models so that experiments can be understood on physical and mathematical grounds.

We adopt the phase-field method to model the three-phase solidifying system, which enables the problem to be addressed by solving a unified set of partial differential equations for the entire system. This approach eliminates the need for explicitly tracking or imposing boundary conditions at the interfaces, significantly simplifying the numerical treatment of complex geometries and dynamic interface evolution. While substantial progress has been achieved in studying two-phase fluid flow systems and contact line dynamics using the phase-field method, the extension to three-phase solidification systems introduces additional layers of complexity. These challenges stem from the need to accurately capture the interplay among three distinct phases, the evolving interfacial morphology, and the anisotropic solidification dynamics, all of which require more sophisticated modeling, numerical algorithms, and analysis to fully understand and predict system behavior.

Hence, in this project, we achieve the following objectives: we (i) derive suitable energetic variational models for the three-phase system that seamlessly couple moving contact line dynamics, non-equilibrium solidification processes, and hydrodynamics under the assumption of quasi-incompressibility; (ii) develop efficient, robust, and easy-to-implement numerical schemes that ensure energy stability and accurately capture the intricate dynamics of interface singularities; and (iii) conduct comprehensive numerical simulations to validate the proposed models and numerical schemes, as well as to explore a range of physically motivated problems, providing deeper insights into the fundamental mechanisms governing these complex systems. The developed computational codes enable the simulation of solidification processes with diverse practical applications. Furthermore, these mathematical models, numerical algorithms, and simulations provide valuable insights into the fundamental mechanisms of these complex systems, contributing to a deeper understanding of physical problems of practical relevance.

At the University of South Carolina, this project provided partial financial support for two Ph.D. students in mathematics, enabling them to make significant progress in their research. The unique training and working experience in both mathematics and mechanical engineering helped the involved students well understand the dynamic interaction between what they learn in computational mathematics and what they need for realistic engineering problems, hence greatly benefit these future applied mathematicians and engineers, whose work will be tightly associated with realistic applications. The PI organized and co-organized mini-symposia at professional workshops/conferences to discuss and to disseminate the proposed methods to a wider audience including engineers and scientists for more efficiently solving their complicated applied problems.
